facts.text: Inspector-General of Police conducted preliminary confidential enquiry and found prima facie case against appellant.

facts.text: Governor referred case to Tribunal under r.4 of Tribunal Rules on charges of corruption, personal immorality and failure to discharge duties properly.

anchor.surface_text: and the Governor acting under r. 4 of the Uttar Pradesh Disciplinary Proceedings  Administrative Tribunal  Rules, 1947-herein- after called the Tribunal Rules-referred the case for enquiry to a Tribunal appointed under r. 3 of the Tribunal Rules on charges of companyruption, personal immorality and failure to discharge duties properly. The Tribunal framed three charges against the appellant, and after a detailed survey of the evidence recommended on February 4, 1950, that the appellant be dismissed from service.

facts.text: Tribunal framed three charges against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Governor then served a numberice requiring the appellant to show cause why he should number be dismissed from service and after companysidering the explanation submitted by the appellant, the Governor ordered that the appellant be dismissed with effect from December 5, 1950. issues.text: whether the procedures under the Tribunal Rules and the Police Regulations are substantially different such as to cause prejudice or violate equal protection

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 490 of the Police Regulations sets out the procedure to be followed in an enquiry by the police functionaries, and rr. 8 and 9 of the Tribunal Rules set out the procedure to be followed by the Tribunal. holdings.text: The Governor had power under s.7 of the Police Act to frame Tribunal Rules and dismiss the appellant; authority not exclusive to Inspector-General.

anchor.surface_text: The authority vested in the Inspector-General of Police and his subordinates by s. 7 of the Police Act was not exclusive. It was controlled by the Government of India Act, 1935, and the Constitution which made the tenure of all civil servants of a Province during the pleasure of the Governor of that Province. The plea that the Governor had nopower to dismiss the appellant from service and such power could only be exercised by the Inspector-General of Police and the officers named in s.7 of the police Act is therefore without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.7 Police Act power not exclusive; controlled by 1935 Act and Constitution; Rules framed under s.7 and preserved by Art.313.

holdings.text: Art.14 has no retrospective operation and does not vitiate pre-Constitution transactions even if discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: But the order of the Governor directing an enquiry against the appellant was passed before the Constitution, and Art. 14 has no retrospective operation it does not vitiate transactions even if patently discriminatory which were completed before the commencement of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Syed Qasim Razvi and Lachmandas; laws valid for past transactions.

holdings.text: No substantial difference between procedures under Police Reg.490 and Tribunal Rules rr.8-9; no prejudice or Art.14 violation.

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 490 of the Police Regulations sets out the procedure to be followed in an enquiry by the police functionaries, and rr. 8 and 9 of the Tribunal Rules set out the procedure to be followed by the Tribunal. There is nosubstantial difference between the procedure prescribed for the two forms of enquiry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detailed comparison shows substantial similarity; hearsay not allowed under natural justice; precedent Sardar Kapur Singh.

holdings.text: r.10 of Tribunal Rules partly invalid insofar as it binds Governor to Tribunal's punishment recommendation; severable.

anchor.surface_text: under r. 10 of the Tribunal Rules, the Governor is enjoined to pass an order of punishment in terms recommended by the Tribunal, whereas nosuch obligation is cast upon the police authority who is competent to dismiss a police officer when an enquiry is held under Regulation 490 of the Police Regulations. To the extent that r. 10 requires the Governor to accept the recommendation of the Tribunal, the rule may be regarded as inconsistent with the Constitution,... The partial invalidity of r. 10 however does not affect the remaining rules

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inconsistent with Art.311(2) pleasure doctrine and reasonable opportunity; severable as guilt finding separate; Governor exercised independent judgment here.

holdings.text: Absence of appeal against Governor's order under Tribunal Rules does not violate Art.14; reasonable classification based on real differentia.

anchor.surface_text: Equal protection of the laws does not postulate equal treatment of all persons without distinctionit merely guarantees the application of the same laws alike and without discrimination to all persons similarly situated. The power of the Legislature to make a distinction between persons or transactions based on a real differentia is not taken away by the equal protection clause. Therefore by providing a right of appeal against the order of police authorities acting under the Police Regulations imposing penalties upon a member of the police force, and by providing nosuch right of appeal when the order passed is by the Governor, nodiscrimination inviting the application of Art. 14 is practiced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Final authority Governor in both; appeal only against subordinates; twin test of reasonable classification satisfied.

holdings.text: Tribunal proceedings complied with Art.311 and natural justice; no right to counsel under either procedure.

anchor.surface_text: but even under r. 8 of the Tribunal Rules, the Tribunal is to be guided by rules of equity and natural justice and is not bound by formal rules of procedure relating to evidence. ... Both the rules deny to the police officer the right to be represented by counsel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedures provide reasonable opportunity per Khem Chand; no counsel in both Reg.490 cl.9 and r.7.

holdings.text: No substance in pleas of irregularities in Tribunal proceedings (no lawyer prejudice, explanation considered, witnesses summoned, assessor consent).

anchor.surface_text: On the materials placed on record, there is nosub. stance in any of the pleas raised by the appellant relating to the regularity of the proceedings of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits show compliance; appellant consent/selection; not controverted.

holdings.text: Tribunal Rules valid overall; enquiry not discriminatory post-Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that there is any substance in the plea that discrimination was practiced by continuing the enquiry under the Tribunal Rules after the Constitution was brought into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance same as alternative; no prejudice shown; Orissa case distinguished.

precedents.citation: Syed Qasim Razvi v. The State of Hyderabad  1

anchor.surface_text: Syed Qasim Razvi v. The State of Hyderabad  1 , this court was called upon to decide whether a trial of an offender companymenced before the Constitution under the Special Tribunal Regulation promulgated by the Military Governor of the Hyderabad State was, since the Constitution, invalid in view of Art. 14.

precedents.case_name: Syed Qasim Razvi v. State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 14 has no retrospective effect; laws inconsistent with Constitution valid for past transactions and proceedings commenced before Constitution
precedents.cited_holding: is not to obliterate the entire operation of the inconsistent laws or to wipe them out altogether from the statute book for to do so will be to give them retrospective effect which they do not possess. Such laws must be hold to be valid for all past transactions and for enforcing rights and liabilities accrued before the advent of the Constitution.

precedents.citation: Lachhmandas Kewalram Ahuja v. The State of Bombay  1

anchor.surface_text: Lachhmandas Kewalram Ahuja v. The State of Bombay  1  in dealing with the validity of proceeding before a Special Judge holding a trial before the Constitution observed As the Act was valid in its entirety before the date of the Constitution, that part of the proceeding before the Special Judge, which, up to that date, had been regulated by this special procedure cannot be questioned, however discriminatory it may have been .

precedents.case_name: Lachhmandas Kewalram Ahuja v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Proceedings under a valid pre-Constitution Act cannot be questioned post-Constitution even if discriminatory
precedents.cited_holding: As the Act was valid in its entirety before the date of the Constitution, that part of the proceeding before the Special Judge, which, up to that date, had been regulated by this special procedure cannot be questioned, however discriminatory it may have been.

precedents.citation: Khem Chand v. The Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: Khem Chand v. The Union of India  1 . It was observed by To summarise the reasonable opportunity envisaged by the provisions under consideration includes-  a an opportunity to deny his guilt and establish his innocence which he can only do if he is told what the charges leveled against him are and the allegations on which such charges are based  b an opportunity to defend himself by cross-

precedents.case_name: Khem Chand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Content of reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2)
precedents.cited_holding: To summarise the reasonable opportunity envisaged by the provisions under consideration includes- a an opportunity to deny his guilt and establish his innocence... b an opportunity to defend himself by cross-examining the witnesses produced against him... c an opportunity to make his representation as to why the proposed punishment should not be inflicted on him...

precedents.citation: Sardar Kapur Singh v. The Union of India  1

anchor.surface_text: In Sardar Kapur Singh v. The Union of India  1 , this court held that by directing an enquiry against a member of the Indian Civil Service who was charged with misdemeanor under, the Public Servants  Inquiries  Act, 1850 and not under r. 55 of the Civil Services  Classification, Control and Appeal  Rules when there was no substantial difference between the material provisions, discrimination was not practiced.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Kapur Singh v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: No discrimination under Art. 14 if two alternative procedures are substantially the same
precedents.cited_holding: discrimination is not practised merely because resort is had to one of two alternative sources of authority, unless it is shown that the procedure adopted operated to the prejudice of the public servant concerned.

precedents.citation: the State of Orissa Dhirendranath Das  2

anchor.surface_text: relied judgment of this Bench in the State of Orissa Dhirendranath Das  2 . In that case, a lower Division Assistant in the Secretariat of the Orissa Government was found guilty of certain misdemeanor by a Tribunal appointed under rules framed by the Orissa Government after an enquiry held in that behalf and was ordered to be dismissed from service.

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v. Dhirendranath Das
precedents.cited_proposition: Discrimination under Art. 14 if executive selects prejudicial procedure out of two substantially different procedures without guiding principle
precedents.cited_holding: If the two sets of rules were in operation at the material time when the enquiry was directed against the respondent and by order of the Governor, the enquiry was directed under the Tribunal Rules which are more drastic and prejudicial to the interest of the respondent, a clear case of discrimination arises

precedents.citation: Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1959  State of Orissa v. Dhirendranath Das

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 103 of 1959  State of Orissa v. Dhirendranath Das . Comparing the Disciplinary Proceedings  Administrative Tribunal  Rules., 1951 of the Orissa Government under which Dhirendranath Das had been proceeded against and dismissed from service with the Bihar and Orissa Subordinate Service Discipline and Appeal Rules, 1935 this Court held that inasmuch as there was a right of appeal to the authority immediately superior to the punishing authority under the Service Rules.

precedents.case_name: State of Orissa v. Dhirendranath Das
precedents.cited_proposition: Proceedings under Tribunal Rules discriminatory compared to Service Rules due to lack of appeal right
precedents.cited_holding: as inquiries could be directed according to procedures substantially different at the, discretion of the executive authority exercise whereof is not governed by any principle, having any rational relation to the purpose to be achieved by the inquiry, the order selecting a prejudicial procedure, out of the two open for selection, is hit by Art. 14 of the Constitution.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: The authority vested in the Inspector-General of Police and his subordinates by s. 7 of the Police Act was not exclusive. It was controlled by the Government of India Act, 1935, and the Constitution which made the tenure of all civil servants of a Province during the pleasure of the Governor of that Province. The plea that the Governor had nopower to dismiss the appellant from service and such power could only be exercised by the Inspector-General of Police and the officers named in s.7 of the police Act is therefore without substance.
vernor exercised his independent judgment and passed an order of dismissal and did number act merely on the recommendation of the Tribunal. The differ
